word.entryDescription: a lot of
word.entryExample: Nowadays, there is plenty of choice for consumers with loads of options from all over the world for each meal.

word.entryDescription: in the area you live
word.entryExample: How would buying local seasonal food help the environment?

word.entryDescription: the position of something, the place where something exists or happens
word.entryExample: The restaurant's central location makes it popular with both tourists and local residents.

word.entryDescription: the capital city of England and Britain
word.entryExample: I live in London.

word.entryDescription: unhappy because you are alone, have no friends or someone to talk to
word.entryExample: Do you sometimes feel lonely?

word.entryDescription: something that is long measures a big distance from one end to the other
word.entryExample: I've got long brown hair.

word.entryDescription: to use your eyes so you can see something
word.entryExample: Look at the board.

word.entryDescription: to take care of or be responsible for
word.entryExample: I must look after Ann's cat this weekend.

word.entryDescription: to direct your eyes at something so you can see it
word.entryExample: Just look at the map!

word.entryDescription: to try to find
word.entryExample: Please help me look for my glasses.

word.entryDescription: to be happy that something will or might happen
word.entryExample: I always look forward to the weekend when I can go out with my friends to the cinema or to eat a pizza.
What do they look like? They look like stars.

word.entryDescription: something you say to warn somebody of sudden danger
word.entryExample: Look out, you're going to fall!

word.entryDescription: to look in a book or on a computer to find information
word.entryExample: He needed to look up the help desk number.

word.entryDescription: a large road vehicle used to carry many things or heavy loads
word.entryExample: Where do you drive your lorry, Michael?

word.entryDescription: to be unable to find
word.entryExample: Be careful - don't lose your money.

word.entryDescription: to forget a number you were trying to count
word.entryExample: Don't worry if you lose count, just keep on starting again from one.

word.entryDescription: become less heavy and less fat
word.entryExample: If you need to lose weight you should avoid fad diets which can actually damage your health.

word.entryDescription: that cannot be found; missing
word.entryExample: Cinderella couldn't find her shoe. It was lost.

word.entryDescription: a large quantity
word.entryExample: We always have lots of vegetables for dinner.

word.entryDescription: a game of chance run by the state, or a charity in which you buy a ticket with a numbers on it and win money or a prize if your numbers are chosen
word.entryExample: He's one of the richest people in the country, after winning the Euro Lottery!

word.entryDescription: making a big sound
word.entryExample: Turn the music down – it's too loud!

word.entryDescription: with much sound
word.entryExample: Could you speak more loudly, please?

word.entryDescription: a room at an airport or port in which you can wait for a plane, ship, etc
word.entryExample: You can't smoke in the departure lounge.

word.entryDescription: to have a strong feeling for someone, or to like something very much
word.entryExample: She loves singing old songs.

word.entryDescription: very pleasant
word.entryExample: We've got a lovely, white cat at home.

word.entryDescription: not high or tall
word.entryExample: If you're hungry, eat more fruit and vegetables – they're high in fibre but low in calories.

word.entryDescription: the state of being loyal to someone/something
word.entryExample: We deserve your loyalty.

word.entryDescription: things, usually good, that happen by chance
word.entryExample: With any luck I'll have found a really interesting job.

word.entryDescription: = fortunately (used to show that something happens due to good luck)
word.entryExample: Luckily, Kate's mum booked a later ferry.

word.entryDescription: all the things that you carry when you travel
word.entryExample: Would you help me with my luggage, please?

word.entryDescription: the food you eat in the middle of the day
word.entryExample: Would you like a salad for lunch?

word.entryDescription: a situation of great comfort and wealth
word.entryExample: Would you really like to lead a life of luxury?

word.entryDescription: very comfortable, attractive and high quality things, usually very expensive
word.entryExample: In times of economic uncertainty people stop spending money on unnecessary items like clothes or luxury goods.

word.entryDescription: created from materials that have not been completely changed and you can still see them
word.entryExample: This watch is made of gold.

word.entryDescription: a thin book with a paper cover which is published regularly and contains articles and pictures
word.entryExample: We are looking for people to write about their favourite gadgets for the magazine.

word.entryDescription: having special powers to make impossible things
word.entryExample: This is not really a magic trick but an impressive stunt.

word.entryDescription: someone who can do magic (in stories) or a person who performs magic tricks
word.entryExample: The magician removed the chairs, leaving the assistant floating in the air.

word.entryDescription: the main part of a meal, often between a starter and a dessert
word.entryExample: For our main course we'd like pasta with chicken, and a pizza, please.

word.entryDescription: to keep something in the same state, standard, etc
word.entryExample: It is often difficult to maintain a happy face all day long.

word.entryDescription: more than a half of the people or objects in some group
word.entryExample: Majority of people lose weight very quickly at first, but then the process slows down.

word.entryDescription: to produce or create
word.entryExample: Mum makes dinner in the evening.

word.entryDescription: to phone someone or somewhere
word.entryExample: I've got to make a call.

word.entryDescription: to earn money by working
word.entryExample: Coober Pedy is a mining town, where people make a living from taking opals from the ground.

word.entryDescription: to do something that is not correct or not a good idea
word.entryExample: Yesterday I made a mistake in my homework.

word.entryDescription: to try to do something that involves hard work
word.entryExample: Could you make an effort and talk with him?

word.entryDescription: to put a make-up (special coloured substances, e.g. lipstick, powder) on someone's face to look more attractive or dfferent
word.entryExample: The hat was really colourful, so she had to make up her face with really bright colours too.

word.entryDescription: to put the covers on your bed in a tidy position
word.entryExample: What time do you make your bed at weekends?

word.entryDescription: an animal of which the female feeds its young on milk from its own body
word.entryExample: Baby mammals drink their mothers' milk.

word.entryDescription: an adult male human being
word.entryExample: Mr Smith is a very kind man.
